intro: Aegiceras malaspinaea, commonly known as the mangrove apple, is a species of flowering plant in the family Myrtaceae. It is a small tree or shrub that thrives in saline and brackish water environments, typically found in mangrove forests. The plant has thick, waxy leaves that help reduce water loss in its coastal habitat. Its flowers are small and white, often clustered in inflorescences, and it produces edible berries that are an important food source for various wildlife. This species plays a crucial role in stabilizing coastal ecosystems and filtering water.
